div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p:
Died, at the residence of her husband, in Culpeper county, April 3d, 1862, Susan R, wife of Malcolm H. Wharton, in the 57th years.
of her age. Earth has seldom known so pure and excellent a lady as the subject of this notice.
Her entire life seemed to be one grand living epistle, which was known and read by all around her to the good of their souls.
In early life she embraced the religion of the Saviour, and to her latest hour exhibited a plods walk and godly conversation, the fruits of which her beautiful spirit is doubtless now reaping in Heaven.
An extract from the affecting tribute paid to her memory in the funeral sermon by her pastor, Rev. James Garnett, of the Baptist Church, can better portray her character than anything that I can say. Said he:

cit.q:
"To say that she was a kind and affectionate wife is but to tell you what you all know; to say that she was the best of mothers, bringing up her children in the nurture and admonition of the Lord, is to tell you what you all know; to tell you that she was a bright and shining Christian, illustrating in her daily life the beauties of the faith she professed, in counseling others in regard to their duties to God, in visiting and ministering to the wants of the affected, and in building up and sustaining the Church to which she belonged, is to state what is familiar to you all. She was always noted for her mild, amiable disposition, gentle manners, and unwavering trust in God.
She was in every respect an extraordinary woman"

div4.p:
--The text seemed eminently befitting the occasion: "To die is gain." Yes, though loss is depicted on the countenances of a weeping husband, of sorrowing children, and friends; though a vacancy has occurred in the Church, which is deeply felt by all; and though a void has been made in the circle in which she moved which this world can never fill, still her loss to us is infinitely her gain.
She has gained a triumph over death and the grave; she has gained a rest from all the disturbing ears and tricks of life, she has gained a place at her Saviour's right hand--

lg.l: "--that place where her hopes were stayed,
For her heart and her treasure were there;
Where verdure and blossoms never fade,
And fields are eternally fair.!

div4.p: Mourners, weep not for her; but as you think of her pure life and its happy, peaceful class, resolve the you will so imitate her example that when your summons shall come, you will be prepared to comely with her last request----"Meet me — meet me in Heaven."
Died, in the city of Richmond, on the 17th day of March, 1862, Mrs. Emily J. Lyle, in the 53d year of her age.

The subject of the above announcement was long and well known in the community in which she resided, and always sustained the character of a devoted parent, affirm and well tried friend, and a sincere Christian.
The lamentations which were audible, and the deep seated mourning which now fills the hearts of those who have been thus bereft, are not only tributes of departed worth, but indications of the estimate formed of her by those whose daily communion enabled them to see those virtues which graced her life.--Frailties, she doubtless had and errors may have merged her course through this world, but let those who are without sin cherish forgiveness.

She was for many years connected with Trinity Methodist Church but it was never her sacred privilege to amend to and enjoy the means of grace.
Nevertheless, her daily walk evinced that she had been with Christ, and we cherish as a fund souvenir the thought that she is now where sickness and that we can never reach her, and enjoying the sureties of her Redeemer.
Her remains were interred in Hanover county, there to remain until the last trump Shall stand and that frail tenement, re-animated, we shall use her again.
By a Friend.

[from the Petersburg Express.]
the death of Gen. A. S. Johnston.
by Lillie.

lg.l: It a far distant State, where the war cloud was looming,
And foes were prepared to subdue our fair land,
This hero was seen, when the cannon was booming.
Loading on to the conquest his brave Southern band.
'Mid the danger of arms and the Innuit of battle,
This brave hearted warrior for freedom was slain,
Around him the missiles of death rudely rattle,
But cannot arouse him to conflict again.
Though the battle sword waves, and the banners are streaming.
The word of command he can utter no more,
While o'er Corluth's fair plain war's red lightning is gleaming.
Energy he sleeps with the chieftain of yore
Around him the noble, the Valliant are bleeding,
And cheering their comrades with life's latest breath,
The wild shout of victory even unheeding,
His sore-throat are hushed in the stillness of death.
With what valor and zeal he has constantly striven,
To repel the destroyer — the blood-thirsty foe,
May his spirit be blest, and rewarded in Heaven,
For all he has born in this valley of wee,
Though the bugle may call and the foes in may battle,
His war-horse will bear him no more o'er the plain,
"He sleeps his last sleep, he has fought his last battle,
No sound can awake him to glory again."
May God help the loved ones, who sadly are mouring
The loss of their cherished, their best earthly friend;
And grant they may meet, on that blest, happy morning,
When life with its trials and conflicts shall end,
Where love is unchanging, and peace dwells forever,
No fears ever fell in the home of the blest,
No foe, joyous friends re-united can sever--
The wicked cease troubling — the weary finds rest.

div3.head: The health of our soldiers.
div3.p:
--The care of our soldiers' health is among the first and most pressing and sacred duties of the Government.
Every consideration of patriotism, interest, and humanity, demands that this duty should be scrupulously and rigidly discharged.
Nothing can excuse any dereliction in this respect.
It is a part of every officer's duty to look constantly to the health of his men. We fear that this has been too much overlooked in some quarters, and we feel sure that me valuable lives have been sacrificed which might have been saved if greater and more systematic provisions had been made to supply our soldiers with proper food in season, and to have it properly cooked.
Warm weather is rapidly approaching, and we may well look for a large increase of disease and death, in consequence, in our armies, unless prompt attention is given to this subject.

We suggested months ago that our soldiers should be spared the drudgery of cooking for themselves.
There is no necessity for it, and the worst consequences result from it. In the first place, it is subjecting them to the performance of menial services from which they ought to be exempt.
They are naturally unfitted for it, do it with reluctance, and do it, therefore, badly.
It is the business of servants, not of soldiers.
In the next place, the cooking which they are compelled to do will be done in the quickest, easiest, and worst manner.

The food thus prepared can only be digested by stomach that are proof against ten-penny nails and camphene whiskey.
Ordinary powers of digestion will succumb to its resistance; and the result, in a word, will be, as experience demonstrates it is, that the hospitals become crowded, many men who manage to keep up will be weak and inefficient, a burden rather than a benefit to the service.

Thirdly, there is not, as we before remarked, the least necessity for it. We have servants for cooks, who understand the business.
In portions of our country which the enemy has temporarily overrun, many citizens have been compelled to remove with their slaves.
The latter are now idle.
Thousands of them could not doubt be obtained as cooks for a moderate compensation, and they could thus be made to render important services to the cause.

Banish camphene whiskey and every other brain-poisoner from the army, absolutely and forever, and supply it with a plenty of food and good cooks.
The one will save officers and men a perfect sea of trouble disaster, and ignominy, and the other will contribute powerfully to the health and comfort, and, therefore, to the efficiency of our soldiers and to the success of our cause.--New Orleans Bulletin.

div3.head: Spirit of our people.
div3.p:
--Nathaniel Seales, of Patrick county, Va., aged about sixteen years, a noble-hearted boy, was killed in the fight near Winchester, a fortnight ago. At least that is the supposition, as one of his comrades saw him fall upon the field of conflict, and he has not been heard of since.
He was one of two twin brothers, both of whom were in that fierce and bloody fight.
He was a youth of noble impulses, manly character, and had been educated at the best schools, completing his education at the Military Institute at Lexington, Va., He entered the war at its commencement, and had endured its privations and sacrifices until he sealed his devotion to his beloved country with his blood.
Noble boy!
he was a hero in the strife.

But our object is not so much to pay a feeble tribute or respect to the memory and exalted worth of this gallant youth, as to refer to the influence which his death had upon the rest of his brothers, three of whom still survive him. Two of them — his twin brother and an elder brother — were already in the field, whilst another had not yet gone forth to war. This brother, when it was announced to him that Nathaniel was slain, instantly remarked that he would take his place, and is already with "Stonewall" Jackson to avenge his country's wrongs and his brother's death.

How can a people be subjugated and deprived of their liberties who have such material for their armies?
It cannot be; no, never!--Rockingham Register

div3.head: About Bonnets.
div3.p: --Since many of our ladies seem to think that the present "coal scuttle" style had its origin in the sunny South, they may be somewhat enlightened by the perusal of the following which we cut from a late Northern newspaper:

A Woman's Thoughts on Bonnets.--The bonnet is the frame to the picture.
A pretty face wants the setting to add lustre to its loveliness.
A homely one hopes, by a happy combination of tints, to soften its ugliness, or to suggest a beauty which it does not posses.--The present bonnets look line coal scuttles, and will hardly succeed in making any one look handsomer.
In their anxiety to grow large all of a sudden, they have burst out behind as well as before.
They may be decidedly stylish, but they are not graceful.-- A high-pointed shelf, protruding over the forehead, and a bag of lace hanging out of the crown, large enough for a work-pocket, is anything but artistic.
Still, it is refreshing to see heads crowned with flowers, instead of feathers.
To me there was always an incongruity in the thought of robbing poor ostriches and smaller birds of their pretty tails, in order to trick out feminine heads.
But flowers are a natural ornament.
Doubtless one of the first things which Eve did was to depot flowers in her hair, and to this day flowers and rare imitations of flowers make the most simple and beautiful adorning of her multiplied daughters.
The most graceful spring hat worn is the simple straw, (void of the silk or lace crown,) trimmed with budded green, or violet tints, and clusters of spring flowers.

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry.
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or Regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time, and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry.

Persons desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call at the office of the Battalion Main street, Richmond, Va., opposite the office of the Southern Express Company
div3.closer:

list.item:
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
Proclamation:
"By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:
"I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, to proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the Department of East Tennessee under the command of Major-General E. K. Smith; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts, to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estate of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and order for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridge, to arouse county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the will of habeas corpus in the Department aforesaid.
"In faith, whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal this 18th day of April. in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
[Signed] Jefferson Davis,"

II. Major General E. K. Smith commanding Department of East Tennessee, discharged with the case execution of the foregoing Proclamation.--He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforces the following orders: All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper,
ap 8--6t Adj't and Inspector General.

div3.p:
Wanted--Recruits to fill up the battalion of Crescent Zouaves, under the command of Major W. Hyllested.
A bounty of fifty dollars will be paid each recruit upon enlistment.
A near uniform of gray cloth, Zouave style, will be furnished.

This corps will be one of the best organized and equipped in the service, and its commander having had many years' military experience, both in this and foreign countries, will make it a battalion worthy of the admiration of his commanding General, and one that young men will be proud to serve in. Those wishing to enlist will apply to
div3.closer:

div3.head: Wise Zouaves!
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of Infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves, in compliment of the memory of the late Captain Wise.
This company will be Instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardingon in the Zouave drill of the French Infantry, and fought by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar in all its detail, and having aided Captain Car!
in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street, one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service.
div3.closer: ap 3--1m C. F. Pardigon.

div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mail to
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,

div3.p:
--From my company, at Camp Winder, on Saturday, April 5th, Christopher Brune.
Said Brune is about 30 years of age, 5 feet 8 inches high, auburn hair, brown eyes, and by profession a ship carpenter.
He wore, when he left camp dark blue coat and pants, grey fatigue cap, with yellow band.

Office on Main and near the corner of 9th street, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Infantry Company.
div3.p: The undersigned being authorized by the Secretary of war to raise a company of Light Infantry for the war, and having united with Mr. Charles H. Exall, and Mr. Wm. J. Eggleston, and G. W. Jones in the enterprise, has opened a Recruiting Office on the West side of 10th street, between Main and Bank. Men enlisting in this company will receive the usual bounty, &c.
This company will form a part of the battalion of infantry being raised by R. G. Scott, Jr., Esq., who may be found at the same office.
div3.closer: [ap 7--1m] John Wickham.

div3.p: I have been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Regiment of heavy Artillery for three years or the war.

This regiment is rapidly filling up, and wents only a few companies requisite to its completion.
I should be glad to confer with captains who have companies, and also with these who desire to raise companies.

p.q: "Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years, or the war, will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered."
